context: For a phylum with relatively few species, ctenophores have a <b4_0>wide range<b4_0/> of body plans. <b5_0>Coastal<b5_0/> species need to be tough enough <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>to withstand <b6_0>waves<b6_0/> and swirling sediment particles<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, while some <a1_0><a1_2>oceanic species<a1_2/><a1_0/> are so fragile that it is very difficult to capture them intact for study. In addition <a1_1>oceanic species<a1_1/> do not preserve well, and are known mainly from photographs and from observers' notes. Hence most attention has until recently concentrated on <b8_0>three<b8_0/> coastal genera – <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b7_0>Pleurobrachia, Beroe and Mnemiopsis<b7_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. At least two textbooks base their descriptions of ctenophores on the cydippid <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>Pleurobrachia<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>.
